title: OVERVIEW
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.

title: GANs
text:
The 1950s marked the beginning of computer graphics as a field. John Whitney, a pioneer in computer graphics, created abstract films using analog computers. In 1958, the film 'Vertigo', directed by Alfred Hitchcock, showcased one of the earliest uses of computer graphics in film, employing a hypnotic spiral effect to represent the protagonist's fear of heights.

 

This effect was created by Saul Bass, a graphic designer and filmmaker known for his distinctive style in title sequences and posters. The spiral effect was achieved using a mechanical analog computer known as the optical printer. This device allowed for the combination of multiple film elements into a single piece of film, using various photographic techniques like matte shots, fades, and color changes. For 'Vertigo,' Bass used a series of mathematically generated spirals and overlaid them on footage of an eye, creating the iconic and disorienting opening sequence. The spirals themselves were produced using a combination of physical mechanisms and photographic tricks, with a rotating spiral pattern filmed against a neutral background.

 

These early experiments laid the foundation for modern computer graphics by demonstrating the potential for technology to create entirely new visual experiences that were impossible with traditional methods alone.

title: CLIP
text: Ivan Sutherland developed Sketchpad in the 1960s, the first graphical user interface and precursor to modern CAD systems. This innovation laid the foundation for interactive computer graphics.

title: LATENT DIFFUSION
text: Ed Catmull, a co-founder of Pixar, developed foundational techniques in 3D graphics, including texture mapping and Z-buffering, allowing for more realistic rendering of 3D objects.

title: UNET
text: Neural networks gained attention in the 1980s, with the rediscovery of backpropagation, essential for training neural networks. Graphics techniques like ray tracing, introduced by Turner Whitted, enabled photorealistic rendering.

title: TOKENIZER
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.
